repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Accounting and Audit
            Organization and Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Accounting and Audit Organization
            and Training Project in Madagascar was implemented. Project
            execution suffered from a number of technical problems,
            since new activities were grafted onto existing ones,
            requiring partial but appreciable reorganization within the
            project and substantial training and retraining of staff.
            These problems have gradually been solved. In the case of a
            multi-phase project, it would be advisable, when successive
            bid proceedings are held for the procurement of equipment
            and machinery, that when subsequent contracts are awarded,
            account be taken of the previous composition of the
            equipment pool in order to reduce the cost of spare parts
            management (reduction of fixed assets) and make maintenance
            more efficient (workers finding it easier to handle a
            standardized pool of equipment). Whenever a project's
            objectives undergo a major revision, care should be taken to
            appraise the short and medium-term fallout likely to result
            from such a revision, with a view to better assuring the
            project's future, during and after project execution,
            on both the economic and the social level.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Accounting and Audit
            Organization and Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project would assist the Government
            to establish an appropriate instructional program to provide
            qualified professionals in accounting and auditing; to
            provide to industry management consulting and audit services
            through existing national companies; and to create a
            suitable legislative framework for the sector. The project
            components are: (a) preparation of appropriate legislation,
            which would require enterprises to prepare audited accounts
            in accordance with specified standards under a national
            accounting code (20 man-months); (b) establishment and
            operation of an accounting training center, to be called
            Centre de Formation en Comptabilite (CFC) and the provision
            of books, supplies, equipment, etc. (279 man-months); (c)
            training and supervisory services to assist the Malagasy
            National Audit Company (RINDRA) (156 man-months); and (d)
            training and technical assistance for Malagasy management
            consulting firms, and a feasibility study for the
            establishment of a public management consulting firm (65 man-months).

Madagascar - Accounting and Audit
